comments.commentBody: IS there any viable, long term, safe solution for the WASTE???  we can talk all we want about C02 emissions, but nuclear waste is more deadly than C02 - at least I would imagine it is, but then again, I am not a scientist.  Just asking the logical question here - what about the waste?  And when we run out of room for that waste, then what?  Jettison it out to space?  Dump it on the "undeveloped" areas of the globe?
Has anyone ever tried to start a car that hasn't run in 23 years? There will be one problem after another and catastrophes that can never be anticipated.

The NRC has only approved one Gen III design and no Gen III+ or Gen IV designs which are more efficient and safer. It's not even looking at LFTRs (Liquid Fluoride Thorium Reactors). I'm sure that TVA merely got approval to restart the design already approved for the site ... a Gen II ... In order to save time and money to get it up and running. It's a shame that the NRC throws up so many obstacles that a company would rather go with an older approved design than run the gauntlet to get a better design approved.

The biggest obstacle to nuclear power and the major source of the increased costs is the NRC. http://www.phyast.pitt.edu/~blc/book/chapter9.html

We need to be moving to LFTRs.

Don't these people watch TV?  Have they heard of Fukushima?   The Germans have the right idea.  Why is there even a debate, we should be closing down nuclear power plants, not thinking of adding any more.

We should not complete a 40-year-old design without a thorough modernization.

But jeez, our continuing ignorance and dilettantism is depressing. If we wait until Greenland melts before getting rid of fossil energy it will be far too late to save our coastal cities and central farmlands. Nuclear power is unavoidably part of the solution. One nuke plant supplies as much power as ten square miles of Solar panels or 100 square miles covered with wind turbines, and does so 24/7.
No more nuclear power reactors should be built until Yucca Mountain is opened up to take the spent fuel from them. Properly encased spent fuel rods should be placed into that repository.

Bad research. The news is next... This has been in the works for quite awhile. TVA has refurbished and brought on line a three old reactors -- at Browns Ferry. TVA was the last utility in the US to construct a reactor from scratch Watts Bar. The first three of these came on line over the Clinton years. Yup, Bill Clinton. I think the opponents are blowing smoke. TVA has a good history of delivering.

I love the general concept. Raised Catholic, we always had 'meatless' Friday, though for some reason fish was fine, as a child I never understood why fish wasn't considered meat.

Anything which is enforced from without is likely to not go over too well, but as an option, or something encouraged, I think it's excellent.

I stopped eating meat in college.  I'm now 60 and am taken for 15 years younger.  I've never gained middle-age weight, my skin glows, my hair shines and I feel fantastic.  But the more salient point is that meat consumption isn't just bad for the health of the individual it's bad for the health of the entire planet.  Why do it?   Why can't most think past their stomachs, culture, and shameless marketing?   Just dumb I guess.

To Commenter #14: in your Meatless Mondays proposition, where are the jobs for all the unemployed? Where is the housing for the foreclosed? Where is tax revenues for all the public programs that we've cut, especially education? And so on.

Let's get behind solving the problems facing our citizens, and let the chickens, pigs, and cows fend for themselves for now. None of them are endangered species....not so sure about me and thee.

My husband and I are both teachers, we're pretty frugal, and we try to be healthy. We don't eat red meat and don't eat copious quantities of poultry and fish. What we do eat in the way of animals is either locally, humanely raised or wild caught by US producers. As a consequence of our eating habits, we don't eat out much. I am always happy when I can find good vegetarian food that meets basic nutritional needs (like protein from grains and legumes). Call me a fan of good meatless meals any day of the week. I think I can safely speak for my husband too: this might help us detour through Aspen on our way to our next western rafting trip. Pass a resolution, Aspen. What could it hurt?
http://ozarkhomesteader.wordpress.com/

i have been vegitarian for last few years, feels healthy, pure from within, solution for depression and positive energy,
less wrinkles, slimmer figure,healthy and stronger and also looking at burgers in differnt way than getting disconnected from the fact that how much sufferring an animal has to go through before its served in plate.

I also don't like the coercive approach. I am a student at Johns Hopkins and was concerned when our cafeteria announced it was beginning meatless Mondays.. Fountunately all it amounted to was a bunch of signs and maybe a little less meat in the cafeteria on Mondays.

Restaurants are free to serve what they want, but I'm also free to eat where I want, and I won't be giving my money to a place spreading the holier-than-thou gospel of vegetarianism. Thanks but no thanks.

"Even if Plato were governing the country, and not Papandreou, the problem would be the same.” However if Obama was governing the country he would save jobs.Poor Greeks looks like they will be force to pay taxes after all.

Sometimes it seems as though the attitude of "I got mine, screw you," that I have seen so widely in the United States is not at all confined to out boarders.

The idea that public good can be financed without everyone chipping in seems to be universal.

Greece will receive bailout money from the IMF and the ECB irrespective of the amount of austerity or the lack of fiscal discipline in the near future in the country.  And, Greek debt will continue to be valued by the 'pretend method of accounting'.  Why?  The chain reaction of having banks fail from what is actually worthless Greek government debt in Greece and then in Germany and France would be the financial equivalent of a nuclear bomb.

The promise of Socialism was that it would, over time, produce a more selfless, empathetic, caring citizen.  With that in mind, is it not interesting to witness legions of Europes finest socialists rioting in the streets because their government might begin to curtail the freebies which were essentially confiscated from those who toiled to produce them?  Socialism produces ingrates.
Malefic consequences of rampant speculation everywhere are showing up and leaving investors concerned about. About time!

Every other comment here states as a known fact that that bankers were responsible for the world wide financial crisis - Really ??

Bankers certainly created the mechanisms for creation and marketing of excessive debt. And often in a fraudulent manner - there's plenty of blame to go around.

But to set the record straight, bankers DID NOT force countries like Greece or housing speculators to go heavily into debt.

That said, it's still time for banks to take a haircut.

The international banking system is a creation of and and essential component of western capitalist democracy.  It is how we are governed.  If populations are looking now for a change that is more representative they will have to invent them.  Since this will require the expulsion of many existing powerful and vested interests the process is unlikely to be peaceful.

In a sick and twisted way, I'm hoping that the U.S. does try to implement austerity measures.

The first thing that will happen will be that Wall Street will be attacked, burned, and looted by the People. The financial district will be in ruins, literally burning out of control. You think some of these other countries are in chaos, imagine how they'll be when the global banking industry is gone...imagine how your neighborhood will look when everything you think has value is all of the sudden worthless and you're job and everyone else's jobs are gone, kaput...no gasoline in the tank and no gasoline in the tanks at the local service station.

Then, after the federal govt reacts by invoking martial law, the real fun will begin. With much of our fighting force broken after years of fighting in the middle east, it will be up to the local police to control a desperate population. It will be chaos...utter chaos. I'd imagine that when all is said and done, the federal government will fall within 3 months, 1/3 of the population will be dead...one half will be enslaved by local/regional warlords, and the rest will run with small, independent, resistance-like groups trying to preserve free areas and rescue enslaved folks.

It will be ugly...and one can only hope he/she has the skills to survive.

This was a new low for me, watching this entire spectacle unfold. Am I the only one who is shocked by the behavior of the Democrats that came out against him? Is it just me, or is that bald opportunism?
What happened to discretion? To decorm? To dignity? Why didn't they keep ranks and simply respond that the party is discussing the options and leave it at that?
If they wanted to avoid the distraction, they shouldn't have joined the circus. One member after another had to mug for the cameras, release a statement, take a position. It was like watching a parody.

I'm so sick of my political process being a joke. What Weiner did was an embarrassment, but it wasn't nearly as ugly as unabashed political cannabalism. I mean, even Obama chimed in.
What a disgrace. Everybody lost in this circus.

Seriously...you are defending him??? How many members of our Nations political structure must be brought down by such inane actions until they get a clue?

He is a fool....perhaps others will learn an ounce of decorum before acting the modern day equivalent of the King Fool to the press.
I would like to see Mr. Weiner reclaim his seat in 2012.  He did a good job and committed no crime.
